div.p: Dapin, Several days ago, a letter was addressed to you by Mepis Boyd & Rogers & reply re questioning you to procure a verdification of the 6 has tu granted four years ago to the Bank of East Tennessee. There was one thing we forgot to add, that is, whatever change you can get recade, have a provision inserted that it shall not be obligatory upon the company until accepted by vote of the stockholders. Otherwise it might have been often as a precedent for recort eciu our cuduuuts We are all anxiety about the Neiwafer Reid = road bill. I never have seen such a special fulicy of interests prevading all clapesof sociity as is reauiforted upon this subject - Do something for it - don't suctor & crush our hopes.

I am glad to see the Syistatureawake to the subject of beriuar schools. The bell reported in the papers, contains percisiy the provisions suggested by us in an article I write & which was published about one year ago; and of course it reuts every appreciation The office of Superior turdiut of Public Trustendtien, I trust will be restored. It is an important
office and one i should perfer holding to any in the state.
We are pleased at what you have done for the Deaf & Dumb School. I know of no Fusti tution we have that deserves better at the heads of the Legislation

But do not fail to help the Keiwafer Rail wade beu not the Whips of Middle & West Tennessee be wader to see that with a clear majority of twelve in the Ayislar turn, the large partier of the democracy in favor of the rueuhir, if they fail to reach a suitable appropiration it penetrates their party in the state proven? Already here a large number of Whips lucurn discurturted and indifferent to the success of our party, seeing what is the bitter fruits of that success in the present Legislature. Much as they love tis party and their principles they love their country still more. Many influence but all prominent Whips have said they never will again vote for a candidate for Govenor West of the Merutary till the huaten is restored to East Tennessee.

Judge Rusis fruces to tother of him as the East Tenn. Electoral Candidate for the state at large. I saw Mr. Matinleur's uaeur interviewed. Flat view will do. He is received in the first district to offer Mr.

Haynes; and he is the very many I believe who can do it respectfully. Mr. Haynes, by his term in the present Legislation has added much to his popularity & influence, and unless met by an able man he will view over evyerthing in the first district.
When I commenced writing I had in mind the first paragraph. But the letter has grown to its present length.
